GCVieweR 0.1.0
  • Reference

    Create a GC Chart Visualization

    GC_chart.Rd

    Generates an interactive GC chart for genomic data.

    GC_chart(
  data,
  start = "start",
  stop = "stop",
  cluster = NULL,
  group = NULL,
  width = "100%",
  height = "400px",
  elementId = NULL,
  scale_breaks = TRUE,
  scale_break_threshold = 20,
  scale_break_padding = 1
)

    Arguments

    data

    Data frame containing genomic information.

    start

    Column name that indicates start positions. Default is "start".

    stop

    Column name that indicates stop positions. Default is "stop".

    cluster

    Optional column name used for clustering purposes. Default is NULL.

    group

    Column name used for gene grouping to influence color aesthetics.

    width

    Width specification for the chart, such as '100%' or 500. Default is unspecified.

    height

    Height specification for the chart, such as '400px' or 300. Default is unspecified.

    elementId

    Optional identifier string for the widget. Default is NULL.

    scale_breaks

    Logical flag indicating if scale breaks should be employed. Default is TRUE.

    scale_break_threshold

    Numeric value indicating the threshold percentage of the entire range for determining inter-gene regions suitable for scale breaks. Default is unspecified.

    scale_break_padding

    Numeric value indicating the padding percentage of the entire range on either side of a scale break. Default is unspecified.

    Value

    A GC chart widget.

    Examples

    genes_data <- data.frame(
  start = c(10, 50, 90, 130, 170, 210),
  stop = c(40, 80, 120, 160, 200, 240),
  name = c('Gene 1', 'Gene 2', 'Gene 3', 'Gene 4', 'Gene 5', 'Gene 6'),
  group = c('A', 'A', 'B', 'B', 'A', 'C'),
  cluster = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 2)
)
GC_chart(genes_data, group = "group", cluster = "cluster") %>% GC_labels("name")
